Health & Safety for Licensed Child Care Providers, Module C   
Section 3: Emergency Preparedness, Response & Recovery

Reunification Plan

Effective reunification is dependent on how well the plan is written & how accurately it is followed.

1

Contact Info in Emergency Kit

Up to date emergency contact information for each child and staff member should be included in the Emergency Kit.

2

Communicate With Parents About Various Emergency Plans

Communicate with parents about various emergency plans. At the time of new child enrollment and any time the plans are revised, information should be shared with parents about: a) evacuation or shelter-in-place locations, b) what the program will do during a lockdown response, c) what parents will do during a lockdown response and d) all other relevant information regarding the emergency plan.

3

Assign Staff to Contact Parents

Assign staff members and notify parents of who will be responsible for contacting them before, during, and after an emergency.

4

Determine Means of Communication

Determine and inform families of the means of communication. Will you be using text, email, phone calls, or another means to connect with them?

5

Develop Procedures for if Child Requires Transportation for Medical Care

Develop a procedure for if a child requires transportation for medical care. Who will accompany the child? Where will they go?

6

Assign Staff to Contact Parents

Programs also need to have procedures in place in case children can not be immediately reunited with families. Situations may happen like closed roads or a need to stay in a safe or confidential location that could result in a child having to even be kept overnight.

Keep in mind that even after all these techniques, there still will be times that you can’t get an infant to stop crying. If this happens and you find yourself frustrated, make the infant’s safety the top priority and take steps to calm yourself down.
